meta_data.title: Not Plundering After a Victory In the Ancient World Was Very Weird
meta_data.subtitle: ESTHER 9 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Opening song, "" from the album, "" by

transcription_data.text: Hey everybody, I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast, and this is one of those cool double episodes where we just get going on one big idea, and we just gotta split it up over two days. So yesterday we were talking about the history of plunder in the Old Testament and what plunder meant in the ancient world, and today we're looking more at the reality of what it meant, that the Jews didn't plunder on this day of victory in the Book of Esther, even though they had permission from the king to do so. I'm gonna have my wonderful friend, Jeffrey, play some music, and we'll just pick up right where we left off. Again, let me know not. Okay, all right, let me talk to you guys under zero. All right, let me what you guys think, let me tell you all today. Good to see you getting down, Let me do your OK with you. Ready to gear up, for three strikingise dot com.Evil Time drone, the plunder thing as well. The language is, of course you take the stuff, it's your best opportunity ever to harvest all of the progress of the defeated people group. You get all of the human output of generations of this little city, state, this little tribe, this little nation, this little kingdom, whatever. You get that when you beat them. And so it's like, in that respect, it's like one of those phone app games that I see advertised, I've never played one, but where you got like a little stick figure soldier and it has like a little number one next to him. You can pick one of three guys to fight and you pick one. He's got like a little number two next to him, right? He's got two power. And you can pick three guys to fight next. One of them's a 10 and one of them's a two and one of them's a one and you're like, well, I have two and that one's only one. I'm gonna fight him and then you walk over and you whack swords on each other and he dies and now you get his one and now you have three total. You're like, well, now I'm not gonna go fight 10 guy. I'm gonna go fight two guy. You see, you fight him and you just keep bigifying by absorbing everybody else's stuff. That's the growth plan for much of the ancient world, especially the further back you go. And so to not is so weird and counter cultural and it raises the question to the people who are watching this all go down, why didn't you all just grab the stuff and use it to enrich your households? Why did you either leave it or in other situations, pile it up and burn it or in other situations, no individual got to take it and make it a part of their household, but it became a part of the household of God, it became a part of the temple or the tabernacle. Why would you do that? And I think in ancient parlance, outsiders would look at that and say, I don't understand the game they're playing but the followers of the God of Abraham are playing a different game than we are playing. Now don't misunderstand, there's nobody back then who would have been like, well, we don't really do fighting because we think everyone is very special and fighting is inherently mean and we wouldn't want losers to feel bad about having a fight and then losing and we wouldn't like what that would do to our reputation. Other people might think that we are unkind and unaccepting and we want to be those things and all those things I'm making in front of there, I'm not really making fun of those are good values. I'm just saying nobody was like that back then, not at all, it just isn't how people think we have a mountain of unanimous evidence to say, nations thought in terms of you go and you fight and you take what you can get. So this plunder thing, my point is, it's just a way bigger deal when you think about it in the original context than when you think about it now. It means something totally different now and I think if God were writing the Bible right now and I do think God is behind this text, I always want to make that clear. I think if God were putting the Bible together right now and playing out this story right now to try to communicate right now, I think the means would be different because I think we speak a very different language. But remember, this thing was always meant for everybody all the way back to the first deal with Abraham. So you're gonna be a great nation and I'm gonna bless you and the nations will be blessed through you. And then you get to deal with Moses and the nations, the non-Jewish people, they're in view there as well. And the deal is I'm gonna be your God and you're gonna be my people and everybody's gonna know it. Not everybody's gonna know it, Claus is the important one for the purpose of our conversation because if you obey me, I'm gonna bless you. And if you disobey me, I'm gonna punish you and everybody's gonna see this pattern emerge. And they're gonna realize that this thing is real and that it's true. The nations were always in view. Isaiah and Zechariah, as we've discussed, point toward what Jesus does, what Paul writes about in the New Testament and what eventually is visualized in the book of Revelation, which is the summary and completion of all of the theology and the narrative arc of the Bible where all the nations go to the temple to the presence of God and they worship God. They lay down those crowns and acknowledge that God is the one true king, every knee boughs, every tongue confesses. But this plunder thing and then sometimes a lack of plunder thing, which is nobody did, that was a unique way of communicating something about this vision little tidbit of it to the larger ancient world. So fast forward all the way to the tail end of the ancient world. We're getting toward what we categorize as the classical world when we get into Persia and now the word plunder comes back up and no one would be surprised when they encounter Mordecai's edict that we read about in chapter eight says how exactly is it phrase? I mean, just read it to you. Verse 11 chapter eight, the kings edict granted the Jews in every city of the right to assemble and protect themselves to destroy, kill and annihilate any armed force of any nationality or province might attack them and their women and children and to plunder the property of their enemies. Nobody would be surprised when that was in the edict because this is still how we thought about things in the 400s BC. What would have melted people's brains is when the 13th day of the 12th month of a Dar comes around and the fighting actually breaks out under the watchful eye of Mordecai and all around the empire, the Jews win and they win big, but then instead of going their enemies houses and taking all their stuff, which like, come on, bro, you earned it. It's not pretty, but blood stained and all. That's your stuff now. Nobody else has a claim on it. They don't though. They don't go in there and do that and no plunder was taken. And the author of Esther by Mike Quickcount, maybe I'll amend this later, but I think three different times makes it very explicit. They were allowed to plunder by Persian law, but they did not. And in doing so, I think that the author is evoking two things here that you're supposed to catch. The original is what Akkadi easily bit for you and I'm gonna think about a little bit harder. Thing number one, this is not a political squabble even though God is not named in this document. The author of Esther is saying this is a holy war. This is a completion of a holy war that was declared a long time ago that was not resolved, that was still on pause. There was no armistice. This was something of a reloading period that went on for centuries, but this is the third act of an ongoing war that is lasted for a millennium. So the original audience would have read this and been like, oh, whoa, whoa, it's consecrated to the Lord. This stuff, this plunder, it's not for the people who carried it out. Okay, so, you know, red X there on the plunder line of the marching orders. Okay, that helps us connect this with other instances like this throughout the Old Testament. This is indeed holy war, not political squabble. Thing number two, it's gonna melt the brains of the neighbors and it's gonna make them fear the Jews and Mordecai even more, right? Wait a dang minute. They just did this out of self-defense and principle. It wasn't really financially expedient. I mean, I suppose it's financially expedient to not die. You tend to earn more when you're not dead when you can do things and whatnot. But in that respect, this was clearly meant as a message to the Jews and to their neighbors that this is a holy war, not your typical political squabble, and it's meant to reiterate to the neighbors that the Jews are playing a different game and that their God is involved even if his name hasn't come up in this story. So what we're getting here then is just one more place where the screw-ups throughout the Old Testament, that Israelites of Hebrew is the Jewish people committed, Saul committed, this in a sense has been attempt at a closing of that chapter, a writing of that wrong. And I have to thank all of the Jewish audience reading this would have understood that. Probably even all of the Jewish people at the time would have understood that. And maybe even a few people who weren't Jewish would have understood that and connected the dots there as well. All right, we'll keep talking about this dramatic day where so much got settled out next time around. Matt is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. I'll do this again soon.
